Article.ArticleTitle: Effects of exercise on psychological distress in patients with COPD: A systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials.

Abstract.AbstractText: Exercise therapies has been increasingly studied, but there is no consensus on their role in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease patients with psychological distress.

We searched for relevant studies published in PubMed, Embase, Web of Science, and Cochrane Library, with a focus on randomized controlled trials that recorded the impact of exercise on psychological distress.

Twenty-one randomized controlled trials met the inclusion criteria. The meta-analysis indicated a significant improvement in anxiety (standardized mean difference [SMD]: -0.63, 95% confidence interval [CI]: -0.92 to -0.35; P < .001, I2 = 83.6%), depression (SMD: -0.44, 95% CI: -0.63 to -0.26; P < .001, I2 = 62.9%), emotion regulation (SMD: 0.32, 95% CI: 0.08-0.56; P = .010, I2 = 0.0%), and self-efficacy (SMD = 0.61, 95% CI: 0.08-1.04, P < .001; I2 = 74.8%) with exercise.
Our meta-analysis supports the alleviation of psychological distress in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease patients by exercise.
